0 Introduction

Fundamentally, the importance of mathematics in the modern world comes from our ability to know that mathematical statements are correct. Arguably, one of the mathematical ideas that has had the most impact on the world (and continues to have impact) is that of calculus. Almost every area of science and engineering requires some use of calculus and it has been central to our understanding of the world for at least the last two centuries. However, when we start to delve into calculus, we start to get to some statements which may trip us up (and have tripped up many of the greatest mathematicians of the last two centuries). This can (and has) lead to errors in solutions of equations, mistakes in proofs, entire books that are incorrect... This is where Real Analysis comes in: Real Analysis is the rigorous study of the theory of real numbers and functions on the real numbers. It aims to completely clarify (i.e. prove) the statements that we require as mathematicians.

Here are some statements - which of these is true? (Recall that a continuous function is one that “you can draw without taking your pen off the page”)

  • 1 = 0.99999999999999999999999999999…
  • If a,b and c are real numbers and a ≤ b then ac ≤ bc.
  • Every continuous function is differentiable.
  • Every differentiable function is continuous.
  • Given a sequence of differentiable functions which get closer and closer together, they will limit to a differentiable function.
  • There is no continuous curve in the plane (i.e. a curve which you can draw without taking your pen off the page) which covers every point on the plane.
  • Suppose that a function f has f′(a) > 0. Then, near f the function is strictly increasing.

In fact, only the first and fourth bullet points are true and the rest are false! When trying to decide which are true and which are false, you may at some point have felt some uncertainty. Indeed understanding which of these is true starts right at the beginning: What does continuous even really mean? What does it mean for a function to be differentiable? What does 0.9999999999999999... even really mean?

So far, you may have been given vague “definitions” such as the “f′(a) is the slope of the graph of f at a”, or (as above) “f is continuous if you can draw it without taking the pen off the page”. However, when it comes to actually doing anything at all with these, they are useless! For example we couldn’t either prove or disprove any of the above, which is pretty bad given the importance of calculus.

In this course, we will understand more about the real numbers and functions on the real numbers. Starting from just the real numbers, we will see why calculus works and build up the techniques necessary to prove the statements that we need to solve mathematical problems. Beyond this, we will build up proof techniques that will have application throughout your degree.

1 Numbers and inequalities

1.1 Sets of numbers

We start with various different types of numbers. We express these as sets, which you will be learning about in more detail in Core Mathematics - essentially a set is a collection of objects, and we can think of a set as a “box” containing mathematical objects. Here are five very important sets which occur regularly in mathematics:

ℤ+, the set of positive integers:
This is the set of “counting” numbers, that is the set of all whole numbers larger than zero, which can be written as
ℤ+ = {1,2,3,4,…} .

Here we have used set notation, the start of the set denoted by { and the end of it by } (so everything in between is in the set).1

ℤ, the set of integers:
This is the set of all whole numbers, including 0 and negative numbers. That is
ℤ = {…,-3,-2,-1,0,1,2,3,…} .

ℚ, the set of rational numbers
. This is the set of all numbers that may be written as a fraction of integers. That is
ℚ = “any number which may be written as where a ∈ ℤ and b ∈ ℕ”

In the above the ℚ stands for quotients.

ℝ, the set of real numbers:
This is the set of all real numbers, including algebraic real numbers, such as ∈ ℝ and transcendental real numbers, for example e,π ∈ ℝ.
ℂ, the set of complex numbers:
All complex numbers, including for example = i ∈ ℂ.

An object that is in the a set is called an element of that set. To say that an object is in a set we use ∈, so given a set A “x ∈ A” means “x is an element of A”. If we want to say an object isn’t in the set we use . So, for example

7 ∈ ℤ+, 54392375004 ∈ ℤ+, but ℤ+, -10ℤ+ .

Note that in the above, every natural number is also an integer, every integer is a rational number, every rational number is a real number and so on. However, there are real numbers that are not rational numbers, and rational numbers that are not integers and so on.

A set A is said to be a subset of another set B (or we might say A is contained in B) if every element in set A is also in set B. We write this, A ⊆ B. We have that:

ℤ+ ⊆ ℤ ⊆ ℚ ⊆ ℝ ⊆ ℂ .

In this course we will be interested in understanding the properties of ℝ. Our aim is to derive all of the properties of the real numbers, starting only from the fundamental sets described above.

In this course, we will be particularly interested in the real numbers, ℝ. As well as being a set, ℝ has further structures which have been familiar to you since primary school:

ℝ is a field:
The real numbers come with standard operations which are familiar to you, namely addition, subtraction, multiplication and division, that is (+ - × ÷), along with the familiar algebraic properties (for example, for any real numbers a,b,c we know that a × (b + c) = (a × b) + (a × c)).
ℝ is an ordered field:
As well as the above we have an ordering relation <. Specifically, given any two real numbers a,b ∈ ℝ exactly one of a = b, a < b and a > b is true. The ordering < is assumed to have all of the usual properties that you are used to (for example, for any a,b,c ∈ ℝ, if a < b and 0 < c then ac < bc).

Our aim is to use the properties the above properties to build up the theorems that we need. For now, we have a further property that we will assume:

FACT: (The Archimidean property of real numbers) Given any real number x ∈ ℝ there is a natural number n ∈ ℤ+ with x < n.

We now restrict ourselves to these properties and statements that we may derive from these properties! For example, for now we will avoid using functions that we haven’t proven the properties of (or even rigorously defined) functions such as sin(x), cos(x), exp(x), xp for p not an integer. We need to prove the properties that we know about these before using them!

1.2 Modulus and measurement on the real numbers

We now define an important function which will be extremely important to us in this course is the modulus function (or absolute value function). This is written as |x| and is defined by

|x| :=  .

So |4| = 4, |- 2| = -(-2) = 2 and so on. Clearly |x|≥ 0 for all x, by definition.

If we think of real numbers as lying on an infinite straight line, then |x| can be interpreted geometrically as the distance from x to 0. Furthermore, given any pair of real numbers x,y, the absolute value of their difference |x-y| can be thought of as the distance between them. Note that |x-y| = |y -x| for all x and y. For example the distance between 4 and -2 is

We emphasize that this is just a mental model of ℝ which gives a nice interpretation of |⋅|. We are not defining real numbers as points on an infinite line, nor are we defining |x| to be the distance from x to 0.

We will often care about inequalities involving |x|.

Lemma 1.1 For any real numbers x and c, |x| < c if and only if -c < x < c.

In the above “if and only if” means that |x| < c is true exactly when -c < x < c (and |x| < c is false exactly when -c < x < c is false). As mathematicians are busy people, we often shorten “if and only if” to “iff”. The above seems reasonable – we might draw the following helpful picture:


Figure 1: Our intuition for Lemma 1.1.

However, drawing a graph helps with intuition, but does not constitute a proof!

Proof:

Suppose first that |x| < c holds. Note that in this case, 0 < c (as 0 ≤|x| < c). We have two cases to consider:

  • If x ≥ 0 then this implies that 0 ≤ x = |x| < c so we have that -c < x < c.
  • If x < 0, we have -x = |x| < c. Rearranging we have that -c < x. Therefore in this case -c < x < 0 which implies -c < x < c.

As these are the only two possibilities for x, if |x| < c we always have -c < x < c

Now suppose that -c < x < c: Again, this implies that 0 ≤ c (this follows from rearranging -c < c). If x ≥ 0 then |x| = x < c. If x < 0 then |x| = -x < c (where this inequality comes from rearranging -c < x). Therefore we see that if -c < x < c then |x| < c. □

Note that in the above we had to have two steps to prove |x| < c iff -c < x < c. We had to prove both “if |x| < c is true then -c < x < c is true” and “if -c < x < c is true then |x| < c”. In general, we need to do both! There are lots of true statements of the form “If A then B” is true but “If B then A” is false. For example, “If I am wearing a hat then there is someone in the room that I am in who is wearing a hat” is always true. However, “If there is someone in the room that I am in who is wearing a hat then I am wearing a hat” is false in general.

Remark 1.2 There is a second statement which is the weak inequality version (or “≤ version”) of Lemma 1.1:

For any real numbers x and c, |x|≤ c if and only if -c ≤ x ≤ c.

This is also true - the proof is identical to the proof of Lemma 1.1 (with < replaced with ≤). I leave it as an exercise to check this!

Example 1.3 We may see that |x - 2| < 1 is all numbers x that have -1 < x - 2 < 1 or 1 < x < 3. We may think of these as all numbers of distance less than 1 from 2.

Lemma 1.4 (Properties of the modulus) For any x ∈ ℝ we have that

|- x| = |x|, x ≤|x| - x ≤|x| ,

and for any x,y ∈ ℝ we have that

|xy| = |x||y| .

Proof: These follows from the definition of the modulus by checking the two cases x ≥ 0 and x < 0 (similarly to Lemma 1.1). I leave these as an exercise! □

Finally, we come to an inequality which will be very important throughout the course.

Lemma 1.5 (The triangle inequality) Suppose that a,b ∈ ℝ. Then

|a + b|≤|a| + |b| .

Proof: From Lemma 1.4, we have that a ≤|a| and b ≤|b|. Therefore a + b ≤|a| + b ≤|a| + |b|. On the other hand, -a ≤|a|, -b ≤|b| so -a-b ≤|a| + |b|, or (rearranging) -|a|-|b|≤ a + b. Putting these together we have that

-|a|-|b|≤ a + b ≤|a| + |b| ,

so by Lemma 1.1, |a + b|≤|a| + |b| as claimed. □

Corollary 1.6 (The reverse triangle inequality) Suppose that x,y ∈ ℝ. Then

||x|-|y||≤|x - y|

Proof: We have that from the triangle inequality (setting a = x - y, b = y)

|x|≤|x - y| + |y| |x|-|y|≤|x - y| ,

and (setting a = y - x, b = x)

|y|≤|y - x| + |x| -|x - y|≤|x|-|y| .

Putting these together we have that

-|c - d|≤|c|-|d|≤|c - d|

which is equivalent to the statement (by Lemma 1.1 and Remark 1.2) □

Summary

  • We have defined several sets of numbers ℤ+ (the set of positive integers), ℤ (the set of integers), ℚ (the set of rational numbers) and ℝ (the set of real numbers).
  • We say set notation “∈” means “is an element of”, “” means “is an not element of” and “⊆” means “is a subset of”. So for example, 1 ∈ ℤ+, -36ℤ+ and ℤ ⊆ ℝ.
  • The modulus function gives the distance of a point to 0.
  • |x| < c is equivalent to -c < x < c.
  • The triangle inequality holds for any real numbers a and b, that is, |a + b|≤|a| + |b|.
  • The reverse triangle inequality holds for any real numbers a and b, that is, ||a|-|b||≤|a-b|.

2 Sequences

A real sequence is a mapping a : ℤ+ → ℝ, that is, a rule which assigns to each positive integer n some real number a(n). Actually, for sequences, unlike pretty much all other functions, it’s conventional to write the image of n under the mapping a as an instead of a(n), and call it the nth term of the sequence, rather than the “image of n.” It’s also conventional to denote the mapping as (an)n∈ℤ+, or just (an) for short, rather than a : ℤ+ → ℝ. We will follow these conventions.

Often we will specify a sequence just by giving a formula for its nth term.

Example 2.1 an = is a sequence whose first 4 terms are

As n gets very large, an gets very close to 1: for example an = 1 to 3 decimal places for all n ≥ 101. So for n this large, we can approximate the sequence by the constant number 1, provided we’re happy to accept errors no larger than 5 × 10-4. What if we’re a bit fussier than this, and need to know an to at least 5 decimal places? How big must n be before we can approximate an by the constant 1? We need
So, for all n ≥ 1001, an = 1 to 5 decimal places. In fact, however many decimal; places of accuracy we insist on, there is a point in the sequence beyond which, to that accuracy, an is just 1.

Example 2.2 Contrast this with an = sinn, whose first 4 terms (to 5 decimal places) are

The behaviour of this sequence as n grows large is not at all uniform; the terms bounce around seemingly at random with -1 < an < 1.

Sometimes it’s more convenient to define a sequence inductively. In its simplest form, this is when we specify the first term a1, and give a rule for constructing an+1 from an.

Example 2.3 Let (an) be the sequence whose first term is a1 = 1, for which

The first 4 terms of this sequence are
What happens to an as n gets very large? This is actually quite hard to answer directly, even using a computer package such as Maple, because the terms become very unwieldy as n gets even moderately large. For example
and Maple has trouble computing even a30, because the integers involved get so large. We can convert each an to a truncated decimal expansion, using the command evalf, which greatly speeds up the calculation, but this gives rounding errors which accumulate as n increases, so by the time we get to a1000, say,it’s not obvious whether the answer Maple produces (0.02234293705, for what it’s worth) bears any relation to reality.

Another interesting question is whether the large n behaviour of this sequence depends on our choice of initial term, a1 = 1. What if a1 = 0? Or a1 = 1000? We will develop methods which will allow us to show that, whatever a1 we choose, an for large n becomes very close to 0 – despite the fact that we have no idea how to write down an in general!

2.1 Convergence of sequences

In Example 2.1, the terms of the sequence “tend to” 1 as n gets arbitrarily large, whereas in Example 2.2, the terms bounce around indefinitely, without tending to a particular value. We say that an = (n2 + 5)∕n2 converges to 1, while an = sinn does not converge. It is now time to make this concept of convergence precise.

What does this have to do with convergence of sequences? In saying that an = converges to 1, we are saying, roughly, that the terms an are close to 1 for large n. In terms of absolute values, this means that |an - 1| is small for large n. More precisely, we make the following definition:

Definition 2.4 A real sequence (an) converges to a real number L if, for each ε > 0 there exists some positive integer N such that for all n ≥ N, |an - L| < ε. In this case, we will write an → L. The number L is called the limit of the sequence (an), and is often denoted liman or limn→∞an.

Remarks

  • This is the most important definition in this course, and it is vitally important that you understand it thoroughly. It is the first rigorous definition of limit we have encountered. Other definitions of limit (e.g. limx→af(x)) will be constructed from it.
  • The definition says that given any ε > 0, no matter how small, there is a term in the sequence, aN, after which all terms in the sequence lie within distance ε of L.
  • Note that |an - L| < ε is equivalent to L - ε < an < L + ε.
  • If we imagine plotting the terms of the sequence an on a graph (with n along the x axis and an along the y axis), we can construct a geometric picture of what the definition means. Given any positive number ε, construct the horizontal strip of height 2ε centred on the line y = L. Then there exists a point N on the x axis, to the right of which all points on the graph lie in the strip.

    This is true no matter how small we make ε. If we make ε smaller, the strip gets narrower, and the N beyond which all terms lie in the strip (probably) moves to the right.

  • So N will, in general, depend on ε: if ε is large, a fairly small N will probably work, whereas if ε is very small, N will probably have to be very large. For our purposes the important thing is to establish that given any ε > 0 there is a corresponding N which works for that particular ε. The relationship between ε and N is not important, nor is it important to know the smallest N which will work for a given ε.

If I ask you to prove from first principles that a given sequence (an) converges to a given limit L, I am asking you to show directly that, given any ε > 0, there is some N ∈ ℤ+ such that whenever n ≥ N, |an - L| < ε. The key to doing this is to “estimate” (that is, rigorously find an upper bound on) the quantity |an - L|.

Example 2.5 Claim: The sequence an = → 0

Proof: We suppose that we are given ϵ > 0 - to prove that an → 0 we need to find an N ∈ ℕ such that if n > N then |an - 0| = |an| < ϵ. As 1∕ϵ is a real number, by the Archimidean property of the reals, there is an integer N > . Then, for any n ≥ N,

|an| = = ≤ < = ϵ

where we repeatedly used that if a > b then > . □

Note that Definition 2.4 does not say that an “gets closer and closer to L as n gets larger”, because this isn’t necessarily true. For example, the sequence

Note that Definition 2.4 does not merely say that given any ε > 0 there is some N ∈ ℤ+ such that |aN - L| < ε. The definition certainly implies this, but is considerably stronger. For example, consider the sequence an = (-1)n. Then given any ε > 0, there is an N ∈ ℤ+ such that |an - 1| < ε. For example, N = 2 will do for any ε > 0, since |a2 - 1| = |1 - 1| = 0 < ε. But clearly an does not converge to 1. In fact, an does not converge to anything. Can we prove this? Yes:

Example 2.8 Claim: the sequence an = (-1)n does not converge (to any limit).

Proof: Assume, to the contrary, that an → L. Then, given any positive number ε, there exists N ∈ ℤ+ such that |an - L| < ε for all n ≥ N. 2.2 Some limit theorems

It’s very important that you get plenty of practice in proving directly from first principles that sequences converge (i.e. constructing ε–N proofs) because this is the best way to get to grips with what Definition 2.4 really means. It is also good preparation for understanding the proofs of the following basic limit theorems. Once we’ve proved these, we can often use them, together with a few standard examples, such as Examples 2.9 and 2.5, to show indirectly that a given sequence converges, without having to give an ε–N argument.

Proposition 2.11 (Uniqueness of Limits) If a sequence converges, its limit is unique.

Proof: Assume, to the contrary, that a sequence an converges to both L1 and L2 with L1≠L2. Let ε = |L1 - L2| > 0. Since an → L1, there exists N1 ∈ ℤ+ such that, for all n ≥ N1,

Similarly, since an → L2, there exists N2 ∈ ℤ+ such that, for all n ≥ N2,
Now let n be any positive integer greater than both N1 and N2 (for example n = N1 + N2). Then both the above inequalities hold, and so,
that is, 2ε < 2ε, a contradiction. Hence, the original assumption (that (an) has two different limits) must be false. □

So we are justified in speaking of the limit of a convergent sequence.

Definition 2.12 We say that a real sequence (an) is bounded above if its rangeis bounded above, that is, if there exists K ∈ ℝ such that for all n ∈ ℤ+, an ≤ K. Similarly, (an) is bounded below if there is a K ∈ ℝ such that for all n ∈ ℤ+, K ≤ an. We will say that (an) is bounded if it is bounded both above and below.

Proposition 2.13 If a sequence converges then it is bounded.

Proof: Assume an → L. Then given any ε > 0, there exists N ∈ ℤ+ such that, for all n ≥ N, |an -L| < ε. This is true, in particular, in the case ε = 1. Hence, there exists N ∈ ℤ+ such that, for all n ≥ N, |an - L| < 1. Let

which exists since the set is finite. Then for all n ∈ ℤ+, |an - L|≤ K, and hence, L - K ≤ an ≤ L + K. Hence, the sequence (an) is bounded (above by L + K and below by L - K). □

Of course, the converse of this Proposition is false: not every bounded sequence is convergent, as we have already seen (for example an = (-1)n is bounded, but not convergent). If a sequence is convergent, it’s bounded above and below, and it’s not hard to show that its limit must lie between the upper and lower bounds:

Proposition 2.14 If K ≤ an ≤ M for all n ∈ ℤ+ and (an) converges to L, then K ≤ L ≤ M.

Proof: Exercise. The obvious strategy is a proof by contradiction. That is, assume an → L but L[K,M]. Then either (i) L > M or (ii) L < K. Now in each of these cases, show that a contradiction arises. □

Note that a sequence (an) is bounded if and only if |an| is bounded above.

  1. an + bn → A + B,
  2. anbn → AB.

Starting from simple known facts, like 1∕n → 0, we can use Theorem 2.15 to deduce the convergence of a large collection of sequences. For example, 1∕n2, 1∕n3, 1∕n4… all converge to 0:

Now the constant sequence 2 converges to 2 (Example 2.9) and → 0 (Example 2.5), so 2 + → 2 + 0 = 2 by Theorem 2.15(i). Similarly, 1 converges to 1, 7 to 7 and converges to 0 (Example 2.16), so 7∕n2 → 7 × 0 = 0 (Theorem 2.15(ii)), and hence 1 + → 1 (Theorem 2.15(i)). Furthermore, 1 + is never 0, so 1∕(1 + ) → = 1 (Theorem 2.15(iii)). Hence an → 2 × 1 = 2 (Theorem 2.15(ii)). □

Clearly, if we maintain this level of detail in our arguments, we will pass out through exhaustion. So in future, we will use Theorem 2.15 more freely, along the lines of the following example:

Example 2.18 Claim: the sequence an = converges to .

Proof:

by Theorem 2.15. □

Exercise 2.19 Prove from first principles that the sequence in Example 2.18 converges to (i.e. give a direct ε–N proof). It’s good for your (mathematical) soul…

Theorem 2.20 (The Squeeze Rule) Let (an), (bn) and (cn) be sequences such that (an) and (cn) converge to the same limit L. If an ≤ bn ≤ cn for all n, then (bn) also converges to L.

Proof: Let ε > 0 be given. Since an → L, there exists N1 ∈ ℤ+ such that, for all n ≥ N1, |an - L| < ε, and hence, an > L - ε. Similarly, since cn → L, there exists N2 ∈ ℤ+ such that, for all n ≥ N2, |cn - L| < ε, and hence, cn < L + ε. Let N = max{N1,N2}. Then for all n ≥ N,

Hence, for all n ≥ N, |bn - L| < ε. □

Example 2.21 Claim: bn = → 0.

Proof: Let an = - and cn = . Then an ≤ bn ≤ cn for all n ∈ ℤ+ (since -1 ≤ cosn ≤ 1) and an → 0 and cn → 0 (by Example 2.16 and Theorem 2.15), so bn → 0 by the Squeeze Rule. □

Summary

  • A real sequence is a mapping a : ℤ+ → ℝ. We denote the image of n ∈ ℤ+ under the mapping a by an and call it the nth term of the sequence. We usually denote the sequence as a whole by (an).
  • A sequence (an) converges to a real number L if, for each ε > 0 there exists a positive integer N such that, for all n ≥ N, |an - L| < ε.
  • If (an) converges to L, we write an → L.
  • The number L is called the limit of the sequence, sometimes denoted liman or limn→∞an.
  • An ε–N proof of convergence is a direct argument showing that, given any positive number ε, there is a positive integer N such that |an - L| < ε for all n ≥ N.
  • The limit of a convergent sequence is unique.
  • If a sequence is convergent, then it is bounded. The converse is false.
  • The usual Algebra of Limits holds: if an → A and bn → B then
    • an + bn → A + B,
    • anbn → AB, and
    • an∕bn → A∕B (provided B≠0 and bn is never 0).
  • The Squeeze Rule: if an ≤ bn ≤ cn and an → L and cn → L, then bn → L.

3 Sets of real numbers

You will have studied sets in Core Mathematics over the last few weeks, and we now remind ourselves of some set notation.

  • Recall that a set is a collection of objects, real or of the imagination.
  • Given a set A, we write x ∈ A to denote that object x is in set A. This is usually translated into words (when reading the expression) as “x is an element of A”. The expression xA means x is not an element of A.
  • Another set B is a subset of A if every element of B is an element of A. This is denoted B ⊆ A. Note that every set is a subset of itself, A ⊆ A. Two sets A, B are equal if they have precisely the same elements, in which case A ⊆ B and B ⊆ A.
  • We have already seen several sets of numbers such as the real numbers ℝ, the positive integers ℤ+, the integers ℤ and the rational numbers (or quotients) ℚ (see section 1.1).
  • A further very important set if the empty set, denoted ∅. This is the set containing no objects. Do not confuse it with {∅}, which certainly isn’t the empty set since it contains an object (namely, the empty set)!

One of the most common ways of specifying a set is by simply listing its elements inside curly brackets, for example

In general A = {x : P(x)} means the set of objects x for which condition P(x) is true. If part of condition P(x) is that x should be in a particular set, we often move that part to the left of the colon. For example, the set above could be written

Note that ∞ is not a number, so expressions like (a,∞] do not make sense. Intervals which include all their endpoints, that is, [a,b], [a,∞), (-∞,b] are said to be closed. Those which exclude all their endpoints, that is, (a,b), (a,∞), (-∞,b) are said to be open.

    that is, the set of ordered pairs of objects (x,y), where x comes from A and y comes from B. Do not confuse the symbol ×, used in the context of sets, with multiplication.

Example 3.1

3.1 Boundedness and the axiom of completeness

When we first learn about real numbers, it is common to think of them as infinite decimal expansions, that is, expressions of the form

with finitely many digits taken from {0,1,…,9} to the left of a dot (the “decimal point”) and infinitely many to the right (possibly all but finitely many of these being 0). This is OK, but it has some disadvantages: the choice of base 10 for the expansion is pretty arbitrary, and there’s the rather annoying fact that different expansions can represent the same number, for example,
For our purposes, it is better to take a radically different approach: rather than attempt to define the set of real numbers constructively, we will characterize it by stating the properties that we assume it has. These properties come in three stages – we have already seen two of these.

First, we assume that ℝ is a field, that is, a set on which the four basic operations of arithmetic (+,×,-,÷) are well defined and have the familiar properties (e.g. x + y = y + x and x × (y + z) = (x × y) + (x × z)).

Second, we assume that ℝ is an ordered field: it is equipped with an ordering relation <. This is a structure which, given a pair of distinct elements x,y ∈ ℝ, x≠y, determines which of them is the smaller. So, for any x,y ∈ ℝ, exactly one of x = y, x < y or y < x is true. The ordering relation < is also assumed to satisfy the usual properties (e.g. if x < y then x + z < y + z for all real numbers z).

These first two structures (the arithmetic operations and ordering relation) have exactly the properties you’ve been familar with since primary school, so we won’t labour them here.2 In fact, you already know an example of an ordered field, namely the set of rational numbers ℚ.

So what is the difference between ℚ and ℝ? For our purposes, the key difference is that ℝ satisfies an extra property called completeness, while ℚ does not. This property is not familiar from school level maths, so we will study it in some depth. To define completeness requires some preliminary ideas.

Definition 3.2 Let A be a subset of ℝ. An upper bound on A is any K ∈ ℝ such that, for all x ∈ A, x ≤ K. A lower bound on A is any L ∈ ℝ such that, for all x ∈ A, x ≥ L. If A has an upper bound, we say that A is bounded above. If A has a lower bound, we say that A is bounded below. A is bounded if it is bounded both above and below.

Example 3.3 The set A = [-1,2) is bounded above, by 2 for example, and below, by -1 for example. Hence A is bounded. Note that upper and lower bounds are not unique. That is, 2,54,19345π are all upper bounds on A. In fact, any K ≥ 2 is an upper bound on A, and any L ≤-1 is a lower bound on A.

Remark 3.4 It is important not to confuse bounded with finite. A finite set is one containing a finite number of distinct elements. Any finite subset of ℝ will certainly be bounded, but the converse is clearly false: not every bounded subset of ℝ is finite, as the above example shows.

Example 3.5 The set of positive integers ℤ+ is bounded below, by 1 for example (or -54, or -1000). However, it is not bounded above.

Let’s think carefully about what it means to say that a set A is unbounded above. It means that A has no upper bound. Equivalently, every real number K is not an upper bound on A. Hence, given any K ∈ ℝ, there exists x ∈ A such that x > K.

So an alternative formulation of the statement “ℤ+ is unbounded above” is “given any real number K there exists a positive integer n such that n > K.”. We have already seen this property - it is the Archimedean property of ℝ!

Note that ℚ also has the Archimedean Property (given any K ∈ ℚ there is some n ∈ ℤ+ such that n > K).

Given a set of real numbers, we would like to be able to use properties of the largest and smallest element. Our first attempt at a “largest” and “smallest” value in a set could be the following:

Definition 3.6 The maximum of a subset A of ℝ (if it exists) is the element a ∈ A such that for any other b ∈ A, b ≤ a.

The minimum of a subset A of ℝ (if it exists) is the element a ∈ A such that for any other b ∈ A, b ≥ a.

This works well for finite sets (i.e. sets with only a finite number of elements).

Example 3.7 Consider the set A = {1,2,3,5,7}. Then maxA = 7 and minA = 1.

In fact we have already been using this notation - we have written max{N1,N2} for the largest of the numbers N1 and N2, and we now see that really we were writing them as the maximum value of the 2-element set {N1,N2}.

However, this definition starts to break down pretty quickly - for example, we already get into problems with intervals. We would like to say that [-1,2) has maximum 2, but in fact, as 2[-1,2) it has no maximum! Clearly, we want a definition which gives a “maximum” for any set that is bounded above.

Definition 3.8 The supremum of a subset A of ℝ is its least upper bound (if this exists), denoted supA. So supA is a real number with two properties:

  1. supA is an upper bound on A.
  2. No number less than supA is an upper bound on A.

Similarly the infimum of A is its greatest lower bound (if this exists), denoted inf A.

It follows immediately from the definition that supA, if it exists, is unique. For if two numbers both satisfy the above two properties and are different, then the smaller of them, K1 say, is an upper bound on A by (i), and is less than the larger one, K2 say, contradicting (ii). So it makes sense to speak of the supremum and/or infimum of a subset of ℝ, in contrast to upper/lower bounds.


Figure 2: Picture of upper and lower bounds, and the supremum and infimum for a set A (shaded in) on the number line ℝ

Example 3.9 Let A = [-1,2). Then, immediately from the definition of this kind of interval, supA = 2 and inf A = -1.

Example 3.10 Let A = { : n ∈ ℤ+}. Every element of A is positive, so A is bounded below, by 0. In fact, inf A = 0. Let’s prove this. We already know that 0 is a lower bound on A, so it just remains to show that every number bigger than 0 is not a lower bound on A. So, let K > 0. Then 1∕K is a real number, so by the Archimedean Property, there exists some n ∈ ℤ+ such that n > 1∕K. But then 1∕n ∈ A and 1∕n < K, so K is not a lower bound on A.

The supremum is a bit less subtle. I claim that supA = 1. Again, let’s prove this. Let x ∈ A. Then x = 1∕n for some n ∈ ℤ+. But n ≥ 1, so x ≤ 1. Hence 1 is an upper bound on A. Any K < 1 is not an upper bound on A, since 1 ∈ A.

The existence of suprema (= plural of supremum) is the defining difference between ℝ and ℚ.

Axiom 3.11 (The Axiom of Completeness) Every nonempty subset of ℝ which is bounded above has a supremum in ℝ.

The equivalent statement for ℚ (replace ℝ by ℚ in both places) is false. For example A = {x ∈ ℚ : x2 < 2} is a nonempty subset of ℚ (e.g. 0 ∈ A) which is bounded above (e.g. every x ∈ A is less than 2), but it has no supremum in ℚ, that is, there is no rational number r with the required properties that (i) r is an upper bound on A and (ii) no rational number s < r is an upper bound on A. The problem is, of course, that is not rational, and there is no smallest rational number bigger than .

The axiom of completeness looks rather lopsided: it says that every nonempty subset of ℝ which is bounded above, has a supremum, but says nothing about sets which are bounded below. That’s because the equivalent statement for infima (= plural of infimum) follows directly from Axiom 3.11. Proving this is a good exercise in keeping clear sight of what upper/lower bound and sup/inf mean:

Proposition 3.12 Let A ⊂ ℝ be nonempty and bounded below. Then A has an infimum.

Proof: Let B = {-x : x ∈ A}, which is certainly nonempty. Let K be a lower bound on A. Then -K is an upper bound on B. (Check: if y ∈ B then -y ∈ A, and hence -y ≥ K. Hence y ≤-K.) Hence, B is a nonempty subset of ℝ which is bounded above so, by the Axiom of Completeness, B has a supremum, L say. Now -L is a lower bound on A. (Check: if x ∈ A then -x ∈ B, so -x ≤ L. Hence x ≥-L.)

Let M be any real number greater than -L. Then -M < L, and L is the least upper bound on B. Hence -M is not an upper bound on B, so there exists y ∈ B such that y > -M. But then -y ∈ A and -y < M, so M is not a lower bound on A. Hence, no number greater than -L is a lower bound on A. Hence -L is the infimum of A. □

3.2 Some consequences of the axiom of completeness

In this section, we will deduce some basic properties of the set ℝ by using Axiom 3.11. The first of these we have already asserted as Fact: the set ℤ+ is unbounded above. This looks entirely obvious, but is it really? As far as we’re concerned, ℝ is, by definition a complete ordered field (so we are not defining it to be the set of all decimal expansions, for example). Is it really obvious that a complete ordered field cannot have a magic element, x say, which is bigger than every positive integer?

Theorem 3.13 (The Archimedean Property of ℝ) Given any real number K, there is some positive integer n such that n > K.

Proof: Assume, to the contrary, that ℤ+ is bounded above. Then, by Axiom 3.11, ℤ+ has a supremum, U, say. Since U - 1 < U, it is not an upper bound on ℤ+, so there exists n ∈ ℤ+ such that n > U - 1. But then n + 1 ∈ ℤ+, and n + 1 > U, contradicting the fact that U is an upper bound on ℤ+. □

That’s a relief! Note that the only property of ℤ+ we used in the above proof was the “successor property”: if n is in ℤ+, then n + 1 is in ℤ+ also. By an almost identical argument, we can show that any subset of ℝ which has the “predecessor property” must be unbounded below.

Lemma 3.14 Let A ⊆ ℝ be any nonempty subset of ℝ with the property that whenever m ∈ A then m - 1 ∈ A. Then A is unbounded below.

Proof: Assume, to the contrary, that A is bounded below. Then, by Proposition 3.12, A has an infimum, L say. Since L + 1 > L, it is not a lower bound on A, so there exists m ∈ A such that m < L + 1. But then, by our assumption about A, m- 1 ∈ A also, and m- 1 < L. This contradicts the fact that L is a lower bound on A. □

As a corollary of these two results, we can prove that the set of rational numbers must be dense in the set of reals, in the following sense:

Theorem 3.15 (ℚ is dense in ℝ) Between any pair of distinct real numbers, there is a rational number.

Proof: Let’s call the smaller of the two real numbers x and the larger y. By the Archimedean Property, there exists n ∈ ℤ+ such that n > , and hence, ny - 1 > nx. We will show that there exists a rational number of the form m∕n between x and y.

Consider the set

This is nonempty, by the Archimedean Property again (if it weren’t, nx would be an upper bound on ℤ, and hence on ℤ+ ⊂ ℤ). We claim there exists m ∈ E such that m < ny. Assume this is false, so every m ∈ E satisfies m ≥ ny. Then, given any m ∈ E, m - 1 ≥ ny - 1 > nx, so m - 1 ∈ E. Hence, E has the “predecessor property”, so by Lemma 3.14, E is unbounded below. But E is clearly bounded below (by nx) by definition, a contradiction. Hence, the claim is true: there exists m ∈ E with m < ny. But then m is an integer and nx < m < ny, so x < < y, as required. □

Recall that a real number is irrational if it is not rational. Since ℚ is countable, we deduce immediately that the set of irrational numbers, ℝ\ℚ, is uncountable. In particular, there certainly are irrational numbers in [0,1], although we do not yet have a single explicit example of such a number! In MATH1000 you may have seen that can’t be rational, but you have not yet proved that it exists at all! However, if you have completed the first Problem Set, you will have shown this. For now, we will assume that exists, and we will see more on this later in the course. From the existence of a single irrational number, we can easily deduce that the irrational numbers are, like the rational numbers, dense in ℝ:

Theorem 3.16 (ℝ\ℚ is dense in ℝ) Between any pair of distinct real numbers there is an irrational number.

Proof: Let’s call the smaller of the two real numbers x and the larger y. Let w be an irrational number in [0,1]. Then w > 0, so by Theorem 3.15, there exists a rational number such that

Hence w lies between x and y and is certainly irrational (since if w = then w = , which is rational). □

You will also see in Core Maths that while ℚ is countable, ℝ \ ℚ is not. So, between any pair of rationals there’s an irrational, and between any pair of irrationals there’s a rational. But there are more irrationals between 0 and 1 than there are rationals in ℝ! This set ℝ is very, very strange…

Definition 3.17 A sequence (an) is increasing if an+1 ≥ an for all n ∈ ℤ+. It is decreasing if an+1 ≤ an for all n ∈ ℤ+. It is monotone if it is increasing or decreasing.

Remarks

  • It follows immediately from the definition that, if (an) is increasing then an ≥ am whenever n ≥ m. Similarly, a decreasing sequence has an ≤ am for all n ≥ m.
  • It follows that an increasing sequence is automatically bounded below (by a1) and a decreasing sequence is automatically bounded above (again, by a1).
  • Note that it’s possible for a sequence to be both increasing and decreasing! But only if it’s constant.
  • We sometimes refer to a sequence as strictly increasing, meaning an+1 > an for all n ∈ ℤ+.

We have proved that all convergent sequences are bounded, and observed that not all bounded sequences are convergent (an = (-1)n provides a counterexample). We next prove that all monotone bounded sequences are convergent. This is the first limit theorem in which we make direct use of the Axiom of Completeness.

Theorem 3.18 Let (an) be increasing and bounded above. Then (an) converges.

Proof: The set A = {an : n ∈ ℤ+} is nonempty and bounded above, and hence, by Axiom 3.11, has a supremum, L ∈ ℝ. We claim that an → L.

Let ε > 0. Then L-ε < L, so by the definition of supremum, L-ε is not an upper bound on A. Hence there exists N ∈ ℤ+ such that aN > L - ε. But (an) is increasing, so for all n ≥ N, an ≥ aN > L - ε. Further, L is an upper bound on A, so for all n ∈ ℤ+, an < L < L + ε. Putting these two inequalities together, we see that for all n ≥ N

and hence |an - L| < ε. □

Theorem 3.19 Let (an) be decreasing and bounded below. Then (an) converges.

Proof: Exercise. You can modify the above proof (note you’ll need to appeal to Theorem 3.12 rather than Axiom 3.11). Or you can define bn = -an and argue that it is increasing and bounded above. □

Corollary 3.20 (Monotone Convergence Theorem) Every bounded monotone sequence converges.

Example 3.21 Let an = αn where α ∈ (0,1). Claim: an → 0.

Proof: an > 0 for all n, and an+1 = αan < an since 0 < α < 1, so (an) is decreasing and bounded below. Hence, by the Monotone Convergence Theorem, an → L for some L. But bn = an+1 converges to L also (it’s the same sequence, but with the first term omitted), and bn = αan, so by Theorem 2.15, bn → αL. But the limit of a convergent sequence is unique (Theorem 2.11), so L = αL. If L≠0, then α = L∕L = 1, a contradiction. Hence L = 0. □

The key trick in the proof above was to think of (an) as an inductively defined sequence: a1 = α, an+1 = αan. We can try the same strategy for other inductively defined sequences.

Example 3.22 (Example 2.2 revisited) Recall we defined a sequence (an) inductively by specifying a1 and using the rule

Proof: First note that an > 0 for all n, as one can easily show by induction (a1 > 0 and if an > 0 then an+1 > 0 by (3.2)). It follows that

and hence an+1 < an for all n. Hence (an) is decreasing. We have already shown that (an) is bounded below (by 0), so by the Monotone Convergence Theorem, an converges to some limit L. Clearly, the sequence bn = an+1 also converges to L (in fact, this needs to be proven – we will see this shortly in Lemma 4.5). But

3.3 *Uncountability from completeness (supplementary non-assessed material)

Recall that an infinite set A is said to be countable if its elements can be put in one to one correspondence with elements of ℤ+. In Core Mathematics, you will prove/will have just proved that ℚ is countable, and that ℝ is uncountable. More precisely, you proved that the set of all distinct decimal expansions is uncountable. Can we see that ℝ is uncountable directly from our definition (as a complete ordered field)? The answer is yes, and the proof uses essentially the same trick as the one you saw in MATH1025. To make it work without the crutch of decimal expansions, we need to introduce the idea of nested intervals.

A sequence of intervals I1,I2,I3,… is said to be nested if In+1 ⊆ In for all n ∈ ℤ+.

Example 3.23 The sequence In = (0,] is nested. The first few intervals are

In this case, there is no real number which is in every interval In: if x is in I1 then x > 0, and by the Archimedean Property, there exists k ∈ ℤ+ such that k > 1∕x, so x > 1∕k, and hence x fails to be in Ik. □

It is a fundamental property of nested sequences of closed intervals In = [an,bn], that there always exists a real number which is simultaneously in every In.

Lemma 3.24 (Nested Intervals Lemma) Let In = [an,bn] be a nested sequence of closed intervals. Then there exists x ∈ ℝ such that x ∈ In for all n ∈ ℤ+.

Proof: Consider the set A = {an : n ∈ ℤ+}, which is certainly nonempty. Let m ∈ ℤ+ and consider bm, the upper endpoint of Im. Let n ∈ ℤ+. If n ≥ m then, by the nesting property, [an,bn] ⊆ [am,bm], so an ∈ [am,bm] and hence an ≤ bm. If n < m then, by the nesting property, [am,bm] ⊆ [an,bn], so bm ∈ [an,bn] and hence bm ≥ an. Hence, for all n ∈ ℤ+, an ≤ bm, that is, bm is an upper bound on A. Since A is nonempty and bounded above, it has, by the Axiom of Completeness, a supremum, x say. We claim that x ∈ In for all n. Since x is an upper bound on A, x ≥ an for all n ∈ ℤ+. Further, as we just showed, every bn is an upper bound on A, so x ≤ bn for all n ∈ ℤ+ (else it isn’t the least upper bound on A). Hence x ∈ [an,bn] = In for all n ∈ ℤ+. □

It’s not hard to deduce from this Lemma that ℝ must be uncountable. In fact, we’ll show that [0,1] is uncountable, from which the uncountability of ℝ immediately follows.

Theorem 3.25 [0,1] is uncountable.

Proof: Assume, to the contrary, that there is an enumeration {x1,x2,…,xn,…} of all the elements of [0,1]. Let I1 be any closed interval in [0,1] which does not contain x1, I2 be any closed subinterval of I1 which does not contain x2, and so on. In this way, we obtain a nested sequence of closed intervals In such that, for each n ∈ ℤ+, xnIn. By Lemma 3.24, there exists x ∈ [0,1] such that x ∈ In for all n ∈ ℤ+. Hence, x≠xn for all n ∈ ℤ+, so the enumeration of elements of [0,1] misses out x, a contradiction. □

Summary

  • An upper bound on a set A ⊂ ℝ is a number K ∈ ℝ such that x ≤ K for all x ∈ A. A lower bound on A is L ∈ ℝ such that x ≥ L for all x ∈ A. A is bounded above if it has an upper bound, bounded below if it has a lower bound, and bounded if it has both.
  • The supremum of A is its least upper bound. That is, K = supA if (i) K is an upper bound on A and (ii) no L < K is an upper bound on A.
  • The infimum of A is its greatest lower bound. That is, K = inf A if (i) K is a lower bound on A and (ii) no L > K is a lower bound on A.
  • ℝ is, by definition, an ordered field which additionally satisfies the Axiom of Completeness: every nonempty subset of ℝ which is bounded above has a supremum in ℝ.
  • It follows from this definition that:
    • ℝ has the Archimedean Property: given any K ∈ ℝ, there exists n ∈ ℤ+ such that n > K.
    • ℚ is dense in ℝ: between any pair of distinct real numbers, there is a rational number.
    • ℝ\ℚ is dense in ℝ: between any pair of distinct real numbers, there is an irrational number.
  • A sequence is increasing if an+1 ≥ an for all n ∈ ℤ+. A sequence is decreasing if an+1 ≤ an for all n ∈ ℤ+. A sequence is monotone if it is either increasing or decreasing.
  • Monotone convergence theorem states that any bounded monotone sequence converges.

4 Subsequences

4.1 Definition and convergence properties

Definition 4.1 A sequence (bk) is a subsequence of a sequence (an) if there exists a strictly increasing sequence of positive integers (nk) such that bk = ank for all k ∈ ℤ+.

In other words, all the terms of (bk) must occur in (an), and they must occur in the same order, but we are allowed to omit some (possibly infinitely many) terms from (an).

Example 4.2

  1. The constant sequence (bk) = (1,1,1,1,…) is a subsequence of an = (-1)n, with nk = 2k. It’s the subsequence consisting of only the even-numbered terms of (an). From this example we see that a divergent (that is non-convergent) sequence can have a convergent subsequence.
  2. bk = is a subsequence of an = 1∕n, with nk = 2k. In this case, both (an) and (bk) converge, and their limits are equal.
  3. bk = is not a subsequence of an = 1∕n even though every term of (bk) is the reciprocal of a positive integer, so appears somewhere in the sequence (an). The problem is that the terms don’t occur in the right order:
  4. Every sequence (an) is a subsequence of itself! We take nk to be the increasing sequence nk = k.
  5. Given any sequence (an), and any positive integer p, bk = ak+p is a subsequence of (an), with nk = k + p. This is just the subsequence obtained by omitting the first p terms terms of (an).

□

As we have seen, it is possible for a divergent sequence to have a convergent subsequence. On the other hand, if a sequence is convergent, with limit L, one expects that all its subsequences should also converge to L. This turns out to be true.

Theorem 4.3 If an → L and (bk) is a subsequence of (an), then bk → L.

Proof: Let ε > 0 be given. Since an → L, there exists N ∈ ℤ+ such that |an -L| < ε for all n ≥ N. Since (bk) is a subsequence of (an), bk = ank where nk is a strictly increasing sequence of positive integers. Now n1 ≥ 1, and if nk ≥ k then nk+1 ≥ nk + 1 ≥ k + 1. Hence, by induction, nk ≥ k for all k. Hence, for all k ≥ N, nk ≥ nN ≥ N, so |bk - L| = |ank - L| < ε. Hence (bk) → L. □

We can use this to give a sneaky proof that an = (-1)n doesn’t converge, without having to resort to an ε–N argument:

Example 4.4 (Equation (2.8) revisited) Claim: an = (-1)n doesn’t converge to any limit.

Proof: Assume, to the contrary, that an → L. Then, by Theorem 4.3, the subsequences a2k and a2k+1 also converge to L. But a2k = 1 → 1 and a2k+1 = -1 →-1, so 1 = L = -1, a contradiction. □

Note that we’ve actually used Theorem 4.3 a couple of times already. In Examples 3.21 and 2.3 (revisited) we asserted that if an → L then bn = an+1 → L also. This follows from Theorem 4.3 since (bn) is a subsequence of (an). It’s important to realize that Theorem 4.3 does not say that if a subsequence of (an) converges to L then (an) converges to L (we’ve already seen a counterexample to this: an = (-1)n). Just showing that a subsequence of (an) converges is not enough (usually) to show that (an) converges. There is an important case, however, where convergence of the subsequence does imply convergence of the whole sequence, namely, subsequences obtained by chopping off the first m terms of the sequence.

Lemma 4.5 (Tail Lemma) Let (an) be a real sequence, m be a positive integer and bn = an+m. If bn → L then an → L.

Proof: Assume bn → L. Let ε > 0 be given. Then there exists N1 ∈ ℤ+ such that, for all n ≥ N1, |bn - L| < ε. Let N = N1 + m. Then, for all n ≥ N, n - m ≥ N1, so

Hence an → L. □

This Lemma is very useful in practice, because it allows us to ignore any number of terms at the start of a sequence when attempting to prove convergence.

Example 4.6 Claim an = converges.

This isn’t immediately obvious, because an is a quotient of functions of n both of which grow unbounded as n gets large, so it’s not obvious whether (an) is even bounded, let alone convergent. To prove convergence, we’d like to use the Monotone Convergence Theorem, but there’s a problem: (an) is neither increasing nor decreasing! In fact
